title: geth crashes with "fatal error: unexpected signal during runtime execution" - DAG
body:
#### System information

Geth version: `1.5.5-unstable`
OS & Version: Ubuntu Linux 4.4.0-57-generic (Ethereum Virtual Machine running on AWS)
Commit hash : (`2dcf75a722f193ef5528f5af8fb4fd7c5824fded`)

#### Expected behavior
geth runs without crashing

#### Actual behaviour
geth crashes after running for a period of time, usually when the system as a whole is idle. In looking at the log, it appears that geth begins to generate a DAG for a particular epoch, and then before that generation is completed, it attempts to generate a DAG for that same epoch. Log entries with line numbers are below.

**Start of first DAG generation for epoch 45:**
`814625 I0117 13:08:04.067881 eth/backend.go:480] checking DAG (ethash dir: /home/ubuntu/.ethash)`
`814626 I0117 13:08:04.068012 eth/backend.go:489] removed DAG for epoch 43 (full-R23-67f3589ac683de3f)`
**`814627 I0117 13:08:04.068084 eth/backend.go:494] Pregenerating DAG for epoch 45 (full-R23-013d5197a3a03514)`**
`814628 I0117 13:08:04.068149 vendor/github.com/ethereum/ethash/ethash.go:259] Generating DAG for epoch 45 (size 1451229056) (013d5197a3a035144a79e3e09dfec250       5039ed176d81a0957e229886ddbee49b)`
`814629 I0117 13:08:04.714497 miner/worker.go:362] ðŸ”¨  Mined block (#1349894 / b4c70c6a). Wait 5 blocks for confirmation`
`814630 I0117 13:08:04.723304 miner/worker.go:563] commit new work on block 1349895 with 0 txs & 0 uncles. Took 8.757975ms`
`814631 I0117 13:08:04.723331 miner/worker.go:458] ðŸ”¨ ðŸ”—  Mined 5 blocks back: block #1349889`
`814632 I0117 13:08:05.286393 vendor/github.com/ethereum/ethash/ethash.go:291] Generating DAG: 0%`



**Later in that same log file, geth tries to generate a DAG for the same epoch 45, but the original DAG generation was still running (got to 47%):**

`814985 I0117 13:10:17.160545 vendor/github.com/ethereum/ethash/ethash.go:291] Generating DAG: 45%`
`814986 I0117 13:10:19.996926 vendor/github.com/ethereum/ethash/ethash.go:291] Generating DAG: 46%`
`814987 I0117 13:10:20.295196 miner/worker.go:362] ðŸ”¨  Mined block (#1349997 / a7d10f3f). Wait 5 blocks for confirmation`
`814988 I0117 13:10:20.304207 miner/worker.go:563] commit new work on block 1349998 with 0 txs & 0 uncles. Took 8.958392ms`
`814989 I0117 13:10:20.304236 miner/worker.go:458] ðŸ”¨ ðŸ”—  Mined 5 blocks back: block #1349992`
`814990 I0117 13:10:20.322157 miner/worker.go:362] ðŸ”¨  Mined block (#1349998 / 49c6e82c). Wait 5 blocks for confirmation`
`814991 I0117 13:10:20.331161 miner/worker.go:563] commit new work on block 1349999 with 0 txs & 0 uncles. Took 8.940344ms`
`814992 I0117 13:10:20.331191 miner/worker.go:458] ðŸ”¨ ðŸ”—  Mined 5 blocks back: block #1349993`
`814993 I0117 13:10:21.478291 miner/worker.go:362] ðŸ”¨  Mined block (#1349999 / 954f3765). Wait 5 blocks for confirmation`
`814994 I0117 13:10:21.487228 miner/worker.go:563] commit new work on block 1350000 with 0 txs & 0 uncles. Took 8.883875ms`
`814995 I0117 13:10:21.487258 miner/worker.go:458] ðŸ”¨ ðŸ”—  Mined 5 blocks back: block #1349994`
**`814996 I0117 13:10:21.487352 vendor/github.com/ethereum/ethash/ethash.go:259] Generating DAG for epoch 45 (size 1451229056) (013d5197a3a035144a79e3e09dfec250       5039ed176d81a0957e229886ddbee49b)`**
**`814997 I0117 13:10:22.648484 vendor/github.com/ethereum/ethash/ethash.go:291] Generating DAG: 47%`**
`814998 fatal error: unexpected signal during runtime execution`
`814999 [signal SIGBUS: bus error code=0x2 addr=0x7ff4985de000 pc=0xbbdc36]`

#### Steps to reproduce the behaviour
Still investigating

#### Backtrace

Could it happen that your machine ran out of memory? It's quite resource intensive to generate the DAG

We have looked into if memory has become constrained and it doesn't appear to be the case. There is plenty of memory at pretty much all times.

From what I can tell it does seem as those two processes are both trying to create a DAG for the same epoch at the same time, instead of the second process either just exiting or waiting for the first to complete.

I wonder if autodag DAG creation and necessity DAG creation are unaware of each other's activities.

Since we created a 32GB swap file, this issue seems to have gone away, so even though it never looked like it was memory constrained, it must have been, as it has been running fine for a few weeks now. I think this issue can be closed.
